body_html:
Sorry, gather_nd does in a similar case. Want to send a PR to update the documentation for those two?
…
On Sun, Oct 15, 2017, 5:39 AM matthias-k ***@***.***> wrote: Where exactly do you fill with a 0? Since in the case of out-of-bounds there is nothing to fill... I'm totally fine with not checking bounds on the GPU but I think it would be very helpful to state in the documentation that on CPU the bounds are checked but on GPU they are not. — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <#13687 (comment)>, or mute the thread <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABtimynz98nXvHhR_cjkgfxynwc5HNqPks5ssfzkgaJpZM4P4ZTQ> .
body_text:
Sorry, gather_nd does in a similar case.  Want to send a PR to update the
documentation for those two?
…
On Sun, Oct 15, 2017, 5:39 AM matthias-k ***@***.***> wrote:
 Where exactly do you fill with a 0? Since in the case of out-of-bounds
 there is nothing to fill...

 I'm totally fine with not checking bounds on the GPU but I think it would
 be very helpful to state in the documentation that on CPU the bounds are
 checked but on GPU they are not.

 —

body:
Sorry, gather_nd does in a similar case.  Want to send a PR to update the
documentation for those two?

On Sun, Oct 15, 2017, 5:39 AM matthias-k <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Where exactly do you fill with a 0? Since in the case of out-of-bounds
> there is nothing to fill...
>
> I'm totally fine with not checking bounds on the GPU but I think it would
> be very helpful to state in the documentation that on CPU the bounds are
> checked but on GPU they are not.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
